block.p: Ford to Lift Fuel Economy Of Sport Utility Vehicles Ford Motor has decided to increase the average fuel economy of its sport utility vehicles by 25 percent over the next five years, people involved in the company's plans said. The increase would be the first significant change in the fuel economy of any class of passenger vehicle in almost two decades.
Ford is convinced that Americans want to buy more fuel-efficient vehicles and will steer their purchases to companies they perceive as environmentally responsible. [Page A1.]

Ruling Could Shut Down Napster In a major victory for the recording industry, a federal judge ordered the Napster online music service to stop permitting the exchange of copyrighted music owned by the major music labels. The lead lawyer for Napster said the company would immediately appeal, but he added that if a stay was not granted by a higher court, the ruling could have the effect of shutting down Napster altogether. [A1.]

Xerox Shares Fall as Profit Declines Xerox said that its second-quarter profit fell by half on lower sales and that efforts to turn around operations would take longer than expected. Although the results met analysts' lowered expectations, shares of Xerox fell $3.1875, to $15. Xerox is facing increased competition and is trying to recover from a failed reorganization that prompted the ouster of its chief executive in May. [C6.]

Auditors Criticize Consulting Plan At a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing, representatives of three major accounting firms strongly criticized a proposal to restrict the types of consulting work that the firms can provide for the companies whose financial statements they audit. [C9.]

Stocks Fall on Profit Warnings Stocks tumbled after several companies warned that their profits would be lower than expected in the second half of the year. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 183.49 points, or 1.7 percent, to 10,516.48. The Nasdaq composite index fell 41.85 points, or 1 percent, to 3,987.72, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index decreased 22.05 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,452.42. [C11.]

Daimler Posts Stronger Earnings DaimlerChrysler posted stronger second-quarter net income but warned that full-year operating profit would face pressure as it disclosed plans to cut costs. ''We will not fully match last year's level,'' the company's chief executive, Jurgen Schrempp, said in a statement, referring to operating profits. The results beat forecasts that were adjusted after previous warnings from the automaker. Its shares rose $1.3125, to $53.5625. [C6.]

Sale of Japanese Bank Postponed Japanese regulators postponed by one month the sale of the nationalized Nippon Credit Bank to a group of investors led by Softbank, one of the world's largest Internet investment companies, after some of Japan's most powerful politicians applied intense pressure to the Financial Reconstruction Commission. [C4.]

Microsoft Argues for Appeals Court Microsoft filed a legal document arguing that the government's antitrust case is ''completely unsuitable for direct appeal'' to the Supreme Court and should go first to the federal appeals court in Washington. [C2.]

Exchange-Traded Funds Gain Favor Exchange-traded funds -- investment pools that are similar to mutual funds but trade like stocks -- are gaining favor among investors and may soon evolve into a viable alternative to a broad range of traditional mutual funds, two new reports predict. Market Place. [C10.]
